liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An additional 43 charges have been laid against a bus driver who was at the wheel of a coach that crashed in the Hunter Valley, killing 10 people. The bus carrying wedding guests rolled on a roundabout near the Hunter Expressway at Greta in June. The new charges include nine offences each of alleged dangerous and negligent driving occasioning grievous bodily harm. There are also 25 new charges of causing bodily harm by misconduct. You can read more on this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hunter Valley wedding bus crash driver faces 43 additional charges

featuredLink.title: Hunter Valley bus crash driver to face 43 additional charges

children.content: An additional 43 charges have been laid against a bus driver who was at the wheel of a coach that
crashed in the Hunter Valley, killing 10 people.
The bus carrying wedding guests rolled on a roundabout near the Hunter Expressway at Greta in June.
The new charges include nine offences each of alleged
dangerous and negligent driving occasioning grievous bodily harm.
There are also 25 new charges of causing bodily harm by misconduct.
You can read more on this story here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ACT government says it will not investigate the leaking of the board of inquiry report into the prosecution of Bruce Lehrmann. Copies of the report have been leaked to the media. The ABC has decided not to publish excerpts of the report for now due to legal reasons. The ACT government has received the report from Walter Sofronoff and said it will stick to its original timetable and release it later in the month after considering its findings. A statement from the Chief Minister Andrew Barr says the leak of the report did not come from the ACT cabinet. The ACT opposition says it's essential the government release the full report.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ACT government says it won't investigate leaking of Lehrmann report

props.alt: A man with a beard and glasses walking outside and wearing a suit.

children.content: (AAP: Mick Tsikas)
The ACT government says it will not investigate the leaking of the board of inquiry report into the prosecution of Bruce Lehrmann.
Copies of the report have been leaked to the media.
The ABC has decided not to publish excerpts of the report for now due to legal reasons.
The ACT government has received the report from Walter Sofronoff and said it will stick to its original timetable and release it later in the month after considering its findings.
A statement from the Chief Minister Andrew Barr says the leak of the report did not come from the ACT cabinet.
The ACT opposition says it's essential the government release the full report.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews and his deputy Jacinta Allan are unlikely to appear before a parliamentary inquiry into the state government's decision to pull out of the Commonwealth Games. In an unprecedented move yesterday, the entire Crossbench voted with the Opposition to force a parliamentary inquiry into the debacle. But the upper house inquiry can't compel lower house MPs to appear — including the premier and former Commonwealth Games minister. Leader of the upper house, Jaclyn Symes, says she won't be encouraging them to appear at the public hearings. "This is an upper house inquiry. The Liberal Party knew that this was the rules of engagement when you have an upper house inquiry. "If they wanted to hear from lower house members they could've come to us and considered another forum."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Daniel Andrews not expected to appear at inquiry into Commonwealth Games cancellation

props.alt: A close up of Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews, speaking outside while wearing a suit and glasses

children.content: (AAP: James Ross)
Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews and his deputy Jacinta Allan are unlikely to appear before a parliamentary inquiry into the state government's decision to pull out of the Commonwealth Games.
In an unprecedented move yesterday
, the entire Crossbench voted with the Opposition to force a parliamentary inquiry into the debacle.
But the upper house inquiry can't compel lower house MPs to appear
— including the premier and former Commonwealth Games minister.
Leader of the upper house, Jaclyn Symes, says she won't be encouraging them to appear at the public hearings.
"This is an upper house inquiry. The Liberal Party knew that this was the rules of engagement when you have an upper house inquiry.
"If they wanted to hear from lower house members they could've come to us and considered another forum."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There's a bit of movement on the ASX today among some companies in the battery metals space. Australian Strategic Materials (ASM), which owns deposits in New South Wales (though is yet to mine anything and sources its rare earths ore from other miners in Asia), has signed a deal with USA Rare Earth. ASM owns a rare earths processing plant in South Korea - that arm of the business has signed a five-year deal with the US company to supply neodymium iron boron alloy from 2024. Neodymium is used to make permanent magnets for things like medical imaging machines, engines and communications technology. It's shares are up more than five per cent. Liontown Resources, which mines lithium (another critical component in batteries) in the Goldfields region of WA, announced today will export lithium direct shipping ore (DSO) (the least refined product) before it exports its first concentrate (ore that's been partly refined) as way to raise some cash. Liontown has so far stockpiled 70,000 tonnes of DSO and expects to sell up to 300,000 tonnes, likely starting by the end of this calendar year. Liontown's Managing Director and CEO, Tony Ottaviano, said: "Progressing with the production of DSO not only provides early revenue potential, but also enables us to de-risk the project by field testing our ore sorting and logistics solutions on a smaller scale ahead of first concentrate production mid-2024." Liontown shares are up 0.2 per cent .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Battery Metals in demand

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's not just a couple of areas where Australians are slashing their spending, it's now pretty much everything. While services spending had remained pretty strong as previously locked down Australians enjoyed their freedom to travel, and eat and drink out, JP Morgan economist Tom Kennedy said almost every retail category fell in the June quarter. " Clothing/footwear sales (+1.1% q/q) were the only category to report an increase in sales volumes, a dynamic the ABS notes owes to additional discounting/promotional activity. " Household goods (-1.5% q/q) and department store (-1.4% q/q) sales posted the largest declines, while cafes/restaurants (-0.1% q/q) and food (-0.5% q/q) sales also lost ground." The overall fall in sales volumes was 0.5% for the quarter, but Mr Kennedy doesn't think the fall in household consumption as measured by the economic growth figures will be quite as steep. "This marks the third consecutive quarterly contraction, an outcome which has happened only once (GFC) in the series' forty year history. "We have previously noted that household spending as measured in GDP is likely to outperform the retail data given the latter largely overlooks spending in the services economy. "We retain this view, but note that the services components of the retail report (for example, cafes/restaurants) also posted declines last quarter which suggests consumption is slowing across the board ." Most states and territories saw declines, although Tasmania and NSW were the standout falls. WA, SA and the NT bucked the downward trend.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Consumption slowing across the board' as inflation, rates bite

consumption is slowing across the board
Most states and territories saw declines, although

WA, SA and the NT
bucked the downward trend.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you were wondering why the Reserve Bank didn't hike interest rates on Tuesday — and many economists were — the detailed retail sales figures offer another strong clue. We had initial monthly retail figures on Friday last week, showing a 0.8% fall in June. But that was a 0.8% fall in the value of goods and services sold, and we all know that prices have generally been going up quite a bit, so the quantity of goods and services sold likely fell even further. Well, today the ABS has released data on the volume of retail sales for the June quarter — a key component of economic growth, as measured by gross domestic product. The news is bleak. Retails sales volumes fell 0.5% in the June quarter, backing up a 0.8% plunge in the March quarter and a 0.4% fall in the three months to December 31 last year. All up, the bureau's head of retail statistics Ben Dorber says the annual number is the worst in more than three decades, if you exclude the pandemic lockdowns. "It's the first time since 2008 that retail sales volumes have recorded three consecutive quarterly falls," he noted in the report. "Retail sales volumes are down 1.4 per cent compared to the June quarter last year. "Outside of the pandemic period, this is the first time since 1991 that sales volumes have fallen compared to the previous year." What was happening in Australia in the early 90s? A very, very nasty recession mainly caused by surging interest rates. Sounds like a pretty good reason for the Reserve Bank to take a break on the rate hikes for now.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Retail sales volumes fall over the year for the first time since 1991

children.content: If you were wondering why the Reserve Bank didn't hike interest rates on Tuesday — and many economists were — the detailed retail sales figures offer another strong clue.
We had initial monthly retail figures on Friday last week, showing a 0.8% fall in June. But that was a 0.8% fall in the
value
of goods and services sold, and we all know that prices have generally been going up quite a bit, so the
quantity
of goods and services sold likely fell even further.
Well, today the ABS has released data on the
volume
of retail sales for the June quarter — a key component of economic growth, as measured by gross domestic product.
The news is bleak.
Retails sales volumes fell 0.5% in the June quarter
, backing up a 0.8% plunge in the March quarter and a 0.4% fall in the three months to December 31 last year.
All up, the bureau's head of retail statistics Ben Dorber says the annual number is the worst in more than three decades, if you exclude the pandemic lockdowns.
"It's the first time since 2008 that retail sales volumes have recorded three consecutive quarterly falls," he noted in the report.
"Retail sales volumes are down 1.4 per cent compared to the June quarter last year.
"Outside of the pandemic period, this is the first time since 1991 that sales volumes have fallen compared to the previous year."
What was happening in Australia in the early 90s? A very, very nasty recession mainly caused by surging interest rates.
Sounds like a pretty good reason for the Reserve Bank to take a break on the rate hikes for now.

items.synopsis: Italian researchers estimate Perucetus, or "colossal Peruvian whale", was about 20 metres long and weighed up to 340 tonnes, a mass greater than the blue whale and the largest dinosaurs.

title.children: Could this 'colossal Peruvian whale' be the biggest animal ever on Earth?
